input.project_name: UPM-Sprinkler Tank Gauge Installation and Fire Pump Return Line Repair
input.status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Jayme Feil

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem: Following the biannual sprinkler tank and system inspection it has been identified that the return line from the fire pump requires repair and a level gauge for the sprinkler tank to be installed to enable safe tank level checks for FM Global and site engineers
scope_of_work.scope: Install level gauge and repair return line
scope_of_work.justification: The return line repair is required to complete FM Global flow test and the gauge negates the health and safety risk of confirming tank water level due to hazardous access above the tank inspection hatches
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: Unable to complete FM Global flow test and H&S hazard will remain

input.associated_items: the assositated items with their boolean values are mentioned: As Builts (No), EANS/CMMS Update (No), O&M Manuals (No), Job Punch List (No), Health & Safety Form (EPIC Form) (No), Single Source Approval (No), Close-Out Checklist (Yes)

output.overview: Project 'UPM-Sprinkler Tank Gauge Installation and Fire Pump Return Line Repair' is located in United Kingdom at site N/A, managed by Qwerty for client Kyndryl. Prepared by Jayme Feil under internal work order UK-EW-02082023-7906. Current status is 'Work in Progress'.
output.project_scope:
The scope notes highlight key considerations: 1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process. The problem statement indicates: Following the biannual sprinkler tank and system inspection it has been identified that the return line from the fire pump requires repair and a level gauge for the sprinkler tank to be installed to enable safe tank level checks for FM Global and site engineers. The defined scope of work includes: Install level gauge and repair return line. The justification provided is: The return line repair is required to complete FM Global flow test and the gauge negates the health and safety risk of confirming tank water level due to hazardous access above the tank inspection hatches. If not approved, the effect would be: Unable to complete FM Global flow test and H&S hazard will remain.

input.status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Flo Hodkiewicz

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem: The cooling towers have 3 fan sections in total with 2 fans on each section. On Cooling tower 3B the blade has cracked. If this fan fails the tower will have to be shut down until repaired, and could create additional works on cooling tower, If we do not carry out the works. It could also result in the resilience of phase 1 site cooling to be at risk
scope_of_work.scope: • Tower will receive a pre-disinfection dose directly to the tower sump -0.5 litres of both ABT1 & ABT2. Tower pre-disinfection will be for 1 hour, minimum • ABT1 & ABT2 levels are to be monitored and logged on the service report sheet. When an acceptable level has been achieved, these details are also recorded on the dynamic risk assessment service report sheet • CBRE with Baltimore Air Coil technicians in attendance will then make the necessary electrical isolations as per the approved FSP • CBRE with Baltimore Air Coil technicians in attendance will manually isolate the flow and return water valves positioned on the tower sump and on the return pipework on the top inspection platform. CBRE with WCS Group technicians in attendance will also isolate the Mains Water inlet valve to stop tower from filling • The Tower will then be drained to the dedicated foul drain using the drain off valve and sump pump • The faulty fan will then be stripped down and replaced with new fan shafts and bearings. • On completion of the fan repair, the other 2 fans on cooling tower 3B will be inspected for damage and where necessary, advise replacement. • After repair to the fan has been completed on the tower, Baltimore Air Coil technicians will, where applied, remove their locks and clasps and CBRE will run the fans and make sure all is ok. Once happy the tower shall be filled back to it’s appropriate levels. • The circulating water will be tested for bromine, ABT1 and ABT2 will be added to boost the level above 100ppm, the bromine level will be monitored every 15 minutes • Once acceptable the tower will be dosed with commissioning dose of inhibitor • On completion of the Tower post-disinfection CBRE will be informed so we can reinstate the electrical supply to the fans and pumps then sign off the permit to work relating to the Tower
scope_of_work.justification: The cooling towers have 3 fan sections in total with 2 fans on each section. On Cooling tower 3B the rear fan blade has cracked and another section has broken off. If this fan fails the tower will have to be shut down until repaired. If we do not carry out the works it could result in the resilience of the site cooling to be at risk
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: The cooling towers have 3 fan sections in total with 2 fans on each section. On Cooling tower 3B the rear fan blade has cracked and another section has broken off. If this fan fails the tower will have to be shut down until repaired. If we do not carry out the works it could result in the resilience of the site cooling to be at risk

It could also result in the resilience of phase 1 site cooling to be at risk. The defined scope of work includes: • Tower will receive a pre-disinfection dose directly to the tower sump -0.5 litres of both ABT1 & ABT2. CBRE with WCS Group technicians in attendance will also isolate the Mains Water inlet valve to stop tower from filling • The Tower will then be drained to the dedicated foul drain using the drain off valve and sump pump • The faulty fan will then be stripped down and replaced with new fan shafts and bearings. • On completion of the fan repair, the other 2 fans on cooling tower 3B will be inspected for damage and where necessary, advise replacement. • After repair to the fan has been completed on the tower, Baltimore Air Coil technicians will, where applied, remove their locks and clasps and CBRE will run the fans and make sure all is ok. Once happy the tower shall be filled back to it’s appropriate levels. • The circulating water will be tested for bromine, ABT1 and ABT2 will be added to boost the level above 100ppm, the bromine level will be monitored every 15 minutes • Once acceptable the tower will be dosed with commissioning dose of inhibitor • On completion of the Tower post-disinfection CBRE will be informed so we can reinstate the electrical supply to the fans and pumps then sign off the permit to work relating to the Tower. The justification provided is: The cooling towers have 3 fan sections in total with 2 fans on each section. On Cooling tower 3B the rear fan blade has cracked and another section has broken off. If this fan fails the tower will have to be shut down until repaired. If we do not carry out the works it could result in the resilience of the site cooling to be at risk. If not approved, the effect would be: The cooling towers have 3 fan sections in total with 2 fans on each section. On Cooling tower 3B the rear fan blade has cracked and another section has broken off. If this fan fails the tower will have to be shut down until repaired. If we do not carry out the works it could result in the resilience of the site cooling to be at risk.

scope_of_work.scope:
• Tower will receive a pre-disinfection dose directly to the tower sump -0.5 litres of both ABT1 & ABT2. Tower pre-disinfection will be for 1 hour, minimum • ABT1 & ABT2 levels are to be monitored and logged on the service report sheet. When an acceptable level has been

attendance will manually isolate the flow and return water valves positioned on the tower sump and on the return pipework on the top inspection platform. CBRE with WCS Group technicians in attendance will also isolate the Mains Water inlet valve to stop tower from filling 
• The Tower will then be drained to the dedicated foul drain using the drain off valve and sump pump • The faulty fan will then be stripped down and replaced with new fan shafts and bearings. • On completion of the fan repair, the other 2 fans on cooling tower 3B will be 
inspected for damage and where necessary, advise replacement. • After repair to the fan has been completed on the tower, Baltimore Air Coil technicians will, where applied, remove their locks and clasps and CBRE will run the fans and make sure all is ok. Once happy the 
tower shall be filled back to it’s appropriate levels. • The circulating water will be tested for bromine, ABT1 and ABT2 will be added to boost the level above 100ppm, the bromine level will be monitored every 15 minutes • Once acceptable the tower will be dosed with 
commissioning dose of inhibitor • On completion of the Tower post-disinfection CBRE will be informed so we can reinstate the electrical supply to the fans and pumps then sign off the permit to work relating to the Tower

scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: The cooling towers have 3 fan sections in total with 2 fans on each section. On Cooling tower 3B the bearings on the single fan has broken down. If we do not carry out the works it could result in the resilience of the site cooling to be at risk

input.status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Brando Dooley DDS

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process (No eBVO Required)
4. Rack to be installed by Kyndryl as a free of charge issue to Ajartec (Cost to install rack and issue of a rack have not been included in this quotation)
5. Use of existing Power Socket under raised floor to be used (Cost to install new socket under floor has not been included, only cost to test existing socket has been included)
scope_of_work.problem: Relocation of CCTV  rack from CSN to CSSE,  this will enable energy savings and allow CSN to be mothballed as the Security CCTV rack for the location is the only rack that remains in within CSN
scope_of_work.scope:
3rd Party contractor to attend site to relocate the clients CCTV Rack from Suite CSN to suite CSSE, part of these works involve installing a cable termination cabinet beneath the floor in the CSN suite and this room should remain accessible if there were any support issues that required investigation in this CSN area. A requirement from the contractor is that a new rack should be in place and the required power in CSSE is also available and tested prior to the relocation of the CCTV servers.
New link cables from the new cabinet in the CSSE suite to be run to an appropriate location under the floor near the existing cabinet location in the CSN suite. The new cables would be terminated into the cable termination box installed beneath the floor. The existing cables would also be terminated in this location to provide for an extension from the existing location to the new location, the contractor to test and inspect on completion. During these works there will be a requirement to break through each rooms firestopping barrier this will need repairing / reinstated on completion of the works.
scope_of_work.justification: Cost saving relocating the CCTV rack from CSN to CSSE this enables the cooling to be turned off and CSN to mothballed.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: Non approval will lead to higher energy costs as cooling will be required within suite CSN , Access to CSN will still be required for issues / servicing for the CCTV rack, CSN  suite can then not be mothballed.

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem:
Following a recent site visit it was found that cooling towers 4&5 require remedial works
The Cooling Tower Ponds of Units 4 & 5 has rust patches and corroded bolts, we recommend the 2 part coating of the Ponds using WRAS Approved Polymer Coating
scope_of_work.scope:
Drain, Prepare and Apply a 2 Coat Polymer Coating to the Cooling Tower Ponds 4 & 5.
Clean and chlorination of ponds upon completion.
Due to curing times of Polymer coating, works are anticipated to take 3 Days followed by chlorination works
scope_of_work.justification:
Legionella regulation requirement.
Leak and long term damage to cooling towers leading to loss of water and increased bills.

input.status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):billing completed by Prof. Miracle Abshire (2):rejected by Prof. Miracle Abshire (3):offer submitted by Prof. Miracle Abshire (4):work in progress by Prof. Miracle Abshire

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem:
Following a visit to site the engineer found the coolant DCA level is low on Generator 2. It is recommended the system is drained, rinsed with water and refilled with a manufacturer recommended coolant, and water filters replaced.
They also recommend an investigation take place to fault find for noise from top end of engine, as there are only two cylinders on left bank.
scope_of_work.scope:
Take possession of generator 2
Isolate generator to prevent starting
Replace old water filters with new provided filters
Drain coolant and store as hazardous waste
Rinse with cold water
Refill coolant system with manufacturers recommended coolant
Check for leaks
Test run generator
Top up radiator if required
Return generator to site use

Carry out an investigation as to find the source of the top end noise,
Rectify any problems, if possible,
Report findings and make recommendations as required,
Ensure area is left clean and tidy
scope_of_work.justification:
Old, dirty or weak coolant will fail to protect the engine components correctly.
Changing the coolant will not remove any debris or scale from the coolant system.
Without the investigation into the abnormal engine noise there is a possibility of engine failure resulting in increased cost.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect:
Old, dirty or weak coolant will fail to protect the engine components correctly.
Without the investigation into the abnormal engine noise there is a possibility of engine failure resulting in increased cost.
